DUTIES OF PCBUs

Safety failings cost company $1 million

 

In 2013, the Supreme Court of the ACT ordered over $1 million in damages to be paid to a man who sustained injuries in the course of his employment at a sawmill.

 

During his employment, the man was required to manoeuvre a trolley weighing between 246 and 677 kilograms that did not have handles or properly functioning wheels. In addition, the floor was not kept clear of sawdust or woodchips, making moving the trolley even more difficult.

 

The employer was found to have failed to comply with requirements that should have identified and assessed hazards, and implemented practical steps to control them.

 

Step 4: Review control measures

 

A person with risk management duties should review and revise a control measure if:

 

•

the control measure is not effective in controlling the risk

•

a change is about to occur at the workplace that is likely to create new or different risks

•

a new risk or hazard is identified

•

consultation with workers, inspectors or others indicates that a review is needed

•

a health and safety representative requests a review

When reviewing a control measure, you should consider all relevant issues, including whether:

 

1.

the measure is operating effectively and as intended

2.

the measure has introduced new risks

3.

safety or supervision procedures are being followed

4.

any training or instruction to workers has been effective

5.

the severity and frequency of incidents has decreased

Safety failings cost company $1 million
